snippet: Britain is among the countries likely to press for the right to require its banks to hold more capital than the European Union minimum.
abstract: European Union finance ministers are expected to work out details over how much capital the union's 8,300 banks should be required to hold; Britain is likely to be among the countries to press for the right to require their banks to hold more capital than the mandated minimum in an effort to reduce the risk to taxpayers; other countries have argued against allowing governments such latitude to raise requirements. (M)

byline.original: By JAMES KANTER and STEPHEN CASTLE

lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS -- European Union finance ministers are expected to wrangle on Wednesday over how much capital the Union's 8,300 banks should be required to hold, a further demonstration of the difficulties of managing a 27-member economic bloc. Britain is among the countries likely to press for the right to require its banks to hold more capital than the E.U. minimum to try to reduce the risk that its taxpayers will be called on to finance future bailouts.

headline.main: Europe Finance Chiefs Are Divided on Bank Capital Requirements
